Award.AwardTitle: Coherent spectroscopy and coherent control of collective modes through shaped optical fields
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project supported by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms Program of the Chemistry Division, Keith Nelson of MIT will develop and use new methods for optical control over molecules and materials. Electromagnetic pulses in the terahertz frequency range will be tailored to drive coherent rotational, vibrational, and electronic responses of polar molecules in order to understand structural and chemical dynamics in molecular gases, liquids, and solids. The terahertz fields will be accompanied by infrared and optical pulses to achieve coherent control over multiple responses that together can lead to structural and chemical change.

The research is based on recently developed methods that have had broader impact as they have been taken up by basic and applied research groups around the world. The methods to be developed are likely to have similar impact and may enable novel applications in ultrafast light-driven switching and signal processing, generation of ultrahigh-frequency acoustic waves, and optical control over molecules and materials. Some aspects of the research are shared in a dedicated outreach lab in which high school students spend up to ten afternoons conducting experiments and analyzing their data, usually followed by presentations of their results in their school classes or science fairs. The students learn about modern optics and advanced materials as they fabricate thin-film samples and make optical measurements involving crossed laser beams that they align to generate and monitor surface acoustic waves that propagate in the films. The noncontact optical measurements are the same as those conducted in one of our labs and in a commercial instrument that is used in the microelectronics fabrication industry for metal film thickness determination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this fundamental research project, we investigated, developed, and applied new types of interactions between light and matter. We used light at widely ranging parts of the spectrum including visible light, much higher-frequency x-ray light, and much lower-frequency far-infrared (or THz) light to induce and monitor novel types of responses in molecules and materials as summarized below.

We used visible light to generate coherent acoustic waves (ultrasonic waves) in liquids and solids. In liquids, we measured the acoustic properties including sound speed and attenuation (damping) to learn about liquid mechanics as the temperature was reduced and a liquid became more and more viscous, eventually forming a solid glass much as molasses or honey does if it is cooled. The measurements revealed “universal” aspects of viscous behavior that provide predictive power for systems such as polymers as they are processed at high temperatures and then cooled to form permanent solid forms. We also studied optically generated acoustic waves in micro-particle arrays, in which the mechanics are controlled by tiny particle contacts with neighbors rather than continuous bulk material. In this case, which is relevant to many systems ranging from sand to cornstarch to nanoparticles, interparticle adhesion and the deformation of local regions around the contacts have far greater impact than usual on the mechanical properties. Using similar methods, we also showed that the degradation of materials such as tungsten under harsh conditions like those in fusion reactors can be measured in a noncontact way. 

We used strong, extremely short-duration terahertz-frequency (THz) pulses to induce a wide range of unusual responses in molecules and materials. In one case, we used the strong, sudden electric field of a THz pulse (only about 1 picosecond, or one trillionth of a second, in duration) to drive electrons in an insulating crystalline solid, vanadium dioxide (VO2), into conducting states, resulting in an insulator-to-metal phase transition. We monitored the material response by x-ray diffraction from the crystal lattice, which showed that the structure of the initial, electrically insulating crystalline phase was gradually transformed into the structure of the final, electrically conducting crystalline phase. The experiment was made possible using technology that we developed in our lab to generate strong THz pulses and using technology that is only available in one major laboratory facility in the world, the x-ray free-electron laser at the Stanford Linear Accelerator (SLAC). In that facility, extremely short-duration (even less than 1 picosecond) pulses of x-ray laser light are generated. We monitored the VO2 phase transition using x-ray diffraction measured at different times after our THz pulse started the process.

We also used the magnetic field component of our THz pulses to drive the collective responses of magnetic materials like yttrium ferrite, YFeO3. A magnetic material has a permanent magnetic moment, familiar from ordinary bar magnets with well-defined “north” and “south” poles. The picosecond-duration magnetic field of a THz pulse exerts a sudden force that can knock the magnetic moment off its natural direction, after which it oscillates about that direction and eventually returns to it. We can measure the dynamics and determine the magnetic (“spin”) oscillation frequency, which tells us about how strong the restoring force is that pulls the magnetic moment back to its initial direction. We did the same thing for molecules with transition metals (like iron or cobalt) that have microscopic magnetic moments (molecular electron spins), measuring their magnetic spin frequencies. These “electron paramagnetic resonance” measurements have wide-ranging applications in chemistry, biology, and materials science. In current work, we are using stronger THz pulses with higher magnetic field levels to try to drive the spin magnetic moments very far away from their initial orientations. In magnetic crystals like YFeO3, we may be able to switch the direction of the magnetic field completely – and if we succeed, it probably will not go back! It will be like switching the north and south directions of a bar magnet, not by moving the magnet at all but by internally switching the magnetic moment directions of all the electrons inside it. If we succeed, we will achieve picosecond magnetic switching and control, with unprecedented applications in ultrafast signal and information processing.

There are myriad light-matter interactions waiting to be discovered and exploited. In this project we advanced our fundamental understanding of some, and we demonstrated applications with broader impact in areas such as fusion reactor monitoring, characterization of micro-particle mechanics used for shock mitigation, and ultrafast control over material structure and electrical and magnetic properties. The research was conducted mainly by graduate students whose broad educations and training in advanced optics and materials enabled them to go on to contribute in academia, in government labs, and in the high-tech private sector.
